text: 30% attendance is roughly what I typically see as well, but I find the more registrations the lower that percentage goes. I've been on a few webinars as a speaker or host over the last few months that had over 1K registered but only about 10% showed up. So I've learned to temper my expectations for live attendance when reg is high.

elements.text: 30% attendance is roughly what I typically see as well, but I find the more registrations the lower that percentage goes. I've been on a few webinars as a speaker or host over the last few months that had over 1K registered but only about 10% showed up. So I've learned to temper my expectations for live attendance when reg is high.

text:
Live attendees at 40% or above is a success in my book. Unless you are able to offer continuing education credits - then it should be higher.

I ran a webinar series last year and we only used our house list. We ran them weekly and started with 300 registrants and ended with 1,000+. Our content worked for the audience (end-users, practical tips) and I think the consistency drove up the registrants. For this program, our live attendance was 50-60%.

elements.text:

text: Yeah it really depends on how targeted you are with the audience, for sure. On the opposite end of the spectrum, I was on a partner webinar recently and one of the audience members asked for an explanation of the topic and if it was related to something completely unrelated. So it made me question how and where they were promoting it.

text:
I have a content team titling question for folks here! I have a Content Marketing Manager who took on managing a direct report last year who helps with writing and editing while he took on a more strategic role. We changed his title  to Senior Content Marketing Manager while his report is Content Marketing Specialist.
• Our HR team is concerned that there isn't a "manager" track for content marketing and that Content Marketing Manager (even tho it has manager in the title) is more of an IC title. And now that we're growing the team, it's been hard to designate his seniority, since he's not yet at Director level. The recommendation (which I don't love) is "Manager, Content Marketing."
Would love to hear from others how they title their content marketing teams - including how managers of the team are designated vs "manager" of a function.

elements.text: I have a content team titling question for folks here! I have a Content Marketing Manager who took on managing a direct report last year who helps with writing and editing while he took on a more strategic role. We changed his title  to Senior Content Marketing Manager while his report is Content Marketing Specialist.

Our HR team is concerned that there isn't a "manager" track for content marketing and that Content Marketing Manager (even tho it has manager in the title) is more of an IC title. And now that we're growing the team, it's been hard to designate his seniority, since he's not yet at Director level. The recommendation (which I don't love) is "Manager, Content Marketing."
Would love to hear from others how they title their content marketing teams - including how managers of the team are designated vs "manager" of a function.

text:
Hello! Does anyone have good examples of an audience deck? Personas, insights, structure, etc. It's _time_ to update ours and I'm trying to combine data from Brand, Comms, Content, Social, Acquisition, Growth, and some user/market research in a way that's clear and helpful to different parts of the marketing team while staying in line with the product team.

I want to look at different ways people lay theirs out for inspiration—and am also open to words of advice on how to approach this. The last time I did it, we had a much smaller team and less inputs.

text: Yeah, this isn’t about titles in the HR system. In this case, that title would be content marketing M5 lol. But am concerned with the title that goes on his LinkedIn, since I can’t yet go with Director. <@U02SU2BECCA> I think Lead might be it!

elements.text: Yeah, this isn’t about titles in the HR system. In this case, that title would be content marketing M5 lol. But am concerned with the title that goes on his LinkedIn, since I can’t yet go with Director.
I think Lead might be it!

text: I think Content Marketing Manager does properly denote that he manages people, whereas if he didn't, I'd expect his title to be more like Content Marketing Strategist or Content Marketing Specialist, while a writer role would be Content Writer (or Copywriter if they also work on ad copy). If he did both strategy and writing, some companies use Content Marketer. Content Marketing Lead is a great alternative to CMM. Head of Content would probably be a step above. My peers and I definitely discuss our titles after signing!

elements.text: I think Content Marketing Manager does properly denote that he manages people, whereas if he didn't, I'd expect his title to be more like Content Marketing Strategist or Content Marketing Specialist, while a writer role would be Content Writer (or Copywriter if they also work on ad copy). If he did both strategy and writing, some companies use Content Marketer. Content Marketing Lead is a great alternative to CMM. Head of Content would probably be a step above. My peers and I definitely discuss our titles after signing!

text: This is a little niche, but does anyone have favorite channels or sites for hosting simple courses (i.e. a mix of video, written content, and maybe Google spreadsheet templates)? I have a client who’s looking into Gumroad but hasn’t been super impressed by the user experience for the course-taker. This is their first foray into a paid course and we’re going to see how it performs, so it’s a little bit of an experiment—and thus we’d prefer to avoid sites that charge a monthly hosting fee. We’re even considering using Notion, if anyone’s seen similar kinds of content projects hosted there. TIA!

text: hmm, closest thing I can thing of is a yes/no matrix I made to determine whether or not to write a content piece for the blog and what category to put it in. It was like "does it have tips or advice for the target customer? if yes, add to category x, if no..." and then arrow to the next qualifying statement, which if yes, points to another category, if no, goes to another qualifying statement. If it gets through all the qualifying statements, we don't post it.

text: Hi all! This is a question for all the single person content teams out there. With a limited flow of content, how do y'all deal with deciding whether your content should be gated/un-gated. Currently I'm working with my demand generation team to decide when/if big content pieces like e-books, playbooks, and quarterly guides should be available to the public and posted on LinkedIn/our website. Any insight is welcome! Thanks! :pray:

elements.text: Hi all! This is a question for all the single person content teams out there. With a limited flow of content, how do y'all deal with deciding whether your content should be gated/un-gated. Currently I'm working with my demand generation team to decide when/if big content pieces like e-books, playbooks, and quarterly guides should be available to the public and posted on LinkedIn/our website. Any insight is welcome! Thanks!

text:
Definitely agree about capitalizing on use cases, and from there, linking to guides. Case study: "How [Company X] Used [Our Company] To [Do Y] and Get {Result X]"
Content Piece: "The Ultimate Guide to Y"
Content Piece #2: "Three Ways to Get [Result X]"
I agree that a newsletter would be great in this scenario. If they're not searching for keywords that can lead them to you, then you need to get access to those that are getting to you and distribute content that way. Don't call it a newsletter though, at least not externally. Have gated assets that automatically enroll them in it, so you'd have to offer freebie downloadables.

elements.text:

I agree that a newsletter would be great in this scenario. If they're not searching for keywords that can lead them to you, then you need to get access to those that are getting to you and distribute content that way. Don't call it a newsletter though, at least not externally. Have gated assets that automatically enroll them in it, so you'd have to offer freebie downloadables.

text: we gate most of our major lead-generating downloadable content, but minor stuff like one-page guides meant for brand building are not gated

elements.text: we gate most of our major lead-generating downloadable content, but minor stuff like one-page guides meant for brand building are not gated

text: I used Asana for this. We had a "Campaigns" folder, and each major category was the name of the campaign. We then would upload each ad of an ad set into the proper campaign, so the image as an attachment and the copy as the description. It worked really well for us.

elements.text: I used Asana for this. We had a "Campaigns" folder, and each major category was the name of the campaign. We then would upload each ad of an ad set into the proper campaign, so the image as an attachment and the copy as the description. It worked really well for us.

text: it's not either/or, it's just different formatting. all of our gated content lives in various blogs that link back to the gated asset. so an ebook has a blog post on each topic covered and a few summary posts (one that goes over each theme; one that pulls all the key stats; etc.). Each individual post links to the ebook as the final CTA.

elements.text: it's not either/or, it's just different formatting. all of our gated content lives in various blogs that link back to the gated asset. so an ebook has a blog post on each topic covered and a few summary posts (one that goes over each theme; one that pulls all the key stats; etc.). Each individual post links to the ebook as the final CTA.

text:
I make the decision by hating gated content myself. User experience over everything. 

I have only ever gated one asset out of the 1,000s I've created or published. That was independent research presented beautifully
